title: Basic Lean Examples
description: A collection of simple example proofs demonstrating basic Lean tactics including non-negativity of squares and implication transitivity.

meta.author: Pedagogical example

mathlibDependencies.description: Product of non-negative numbers is non-negative

originalContributions: Simple examples showing basic proof techniques

overview.historicalContext: These are pedagogical examples demonstrating fundamental Lean proof techniques. They serve as a starting point for learning formal verification.
overview.problemStatement:
**Examples proven:**

1. For any integer n: n * n >= 0 (squares are non-negative)
2. Implication transitivity: (P -> Q) -> (Q -> R) -> (P -> R)
overview.proofStrategy:
The proofs use basic tactics:
- `by_cases` for case analysis on whether n >= 0
- `calc` for step-by-step calculations
- `ring` for polynomial arithmetic
- `intro`, `apply`, `exact` for logical reasoning
keyInsights: Case analysis is a fundamental proof technique
The calc block provides readable step-by-step proofs
Simple lemmas build foundations for complex proofs

sections.title: Squares are Non-negative
sections.summary: Proof that n * n >= 0 for any integer n.

sections.title: Implication Transitivity
sections.summary: Proof that implications compose: (P -> Q) -> (Q -> R) -> (P -> R).

conclusion.summary: These simple examples demonstrate the building blocks of formal proofs in Lean: case analysis, calculation chains, and logical reasoning.
conclusion.implications: These basic techniques are used throughout more complex proofs in mathematics and computer science.
